segments.text: Yeah, so I think that the planetary field has become better integrated with the rest of astronomy.
And that's largely also because planetary studies have, thanks to the amount of money and effort, have been brought up to date.
You have to realize that back in the 30s and 40s, when planetary studies were at their lowest ebb,
The techniques that were used by planetary astronomers were very primitive.

There was an awful lot of what was called physical study of planets, which was taking pictures of them and trying to understand things from just direct photographs, which is not very important and not very useful.
With perhaps different filters?
That's right.
A lot of stuff like tracking dust storms on Mars.
There's still a certain amount of tracking dust storms on Mars that goes on, but that's kind of all there was in those days.
There were a few feeble efforts by people to understand the markings on them.
You have to realize, when I got into this business, there was a huge controversy over the nature of the lunar craters.
There were still people who wanted lunar craters and volcanoes.

Kuiper was one of the first people who pointed out that lunar craters were different from lunar volcanoes and showed that these things that people would call them were genuine volcanoes like the volcanoes in Hawaii.
and pointed that out as a result of compiling the pictures for the photographic data.
And so there was a long period of techniques that were being used by mainline astronomers, particularly spectroscopy, simply weren't being applied to planets.
And after planetary spectroscopy got revived, that quickly showed the need for more laboratory spectroscopy, more molecular things.
molecular spectra have taken over an overriding importance in the Earth's atmosphere because of pollutant detection.

So the portfolio has become, well, I guess that's the other connection, that the whole business of comparative planetology, of comparing both the solid bodies in the atmosphere of other planets with that of the Earth, has made the field a great deal more respectable as well as more well-funded.
And so this has again brought a
more into the mainstream of science and left a little peripheral interest.
Where do you think if there was never been a NASA?
Well, for there never to have been a NASA, there would never have had to be a Sputnik.
And for there never to have been a Sputnik,
I mean, this is really one of these things that's tied in with the current war and the use of ICBMs and rockets for military purposes.
There's a whole broad context there that must be tied together.
Do you think that if there had not been that, they seem willing to do it right now, this year?
Yeah, right.
Hmm.
Well, the Air Force certainly was sponsoring a lot of early studies and things that could be done.
Now, for instance, to give you some notion, again, of a Cold War tie-in, when I had, I guess I hadn't even gotten my Ph.D. yet.
I was a senior graduate student at Harvard.
I was asked by one of the companies around 128, I guess it was somebody out at Lincoln, who
write a study of what could be done with a 100-inch pulse depth of orbit.
And this must have been around 1969 or 60.
And, of course, unbeknownst to me at the time, the Earth Force was in the process of launching 100-inch telescopes in orbit, looking down rather than up.
I was unaware of that.
Right.
I was unaware of that, of course.
and was extremely skeptical at the time that the technology permitted such a thing to be done.
They were talking about a lifetime for the telescope of two weeks to a month, and they wanted projects that could be done quickly in that length of time.

I gave them a rather discouraging report because I thought that testing the optics of the thing would take more time than that, and that it wouldn't be possible to do an awful lot of astronomy with such an object.
And, in fact, we've seen from the Hubble Space Telescope that, in fact, it takes several years to test and correct the optics that's up there.
So maybe I wasn't so far off.
Well, how long did it take them to correct the optics they needed to?
About four to five years.
Yes, it took a while.
Of course, they weren't as well funded as some of these airport problems.
Planetary astronomers now have their own journals.
I would say they're good for both.
The DPS was extremely valuable for planetary astronomy because
you have to remember that that was a time when you couldn't get planetary papers published in the Apt.J.
And so Icarus, like several other journals one could name, was formed as a place for people to publish who couldn't publish in the Apt.J.
You remember Icarus was founded by Copal, who, I think, wrote Journey of Donorite.
And Copal founded it.
Yeah, right.
And then it was taken over by Carl Sagan.
And Carl, as soon as he took it over, tried to build it up and make it a focal point for planetary work, which he was entirely successful in doing.
And concomitant with that, there was an effort by several people, of whom I believe Carl was one, to firm a society devoted to planetary studies.
and to make Icarus the official journal of that society.
The other people came about after a few years, and DPS members have had for a long time a good price break on Icarus subscriptions.
You answered the question I had earlier, what was planetary astronomy like when you started, and now you didn't answer that.
But do you think planetary astronomy is part of astronomy?
Of course, yes.
I always did.
It seems it's a totally different character now.

When you look at the view of the planets, in fact, even when I was still at Harvard, I realized that everything that was accepted proof of our planets in the old planetary astronomy days, there was something drastically wrong about every planet.
Because when I started teaching astronomy, I taught my students that we're doing all these people and things all the time.
that Venus rotates in 24 hours.
Take your pick, either one.
And that the clouds were probably made of water.
Then there was the blue haze on Mars.
Jupiter, let's see, what was there about Jupiter?
The red spot was all wrong.
The red spot was all wrong, yeah.
There was a Taylor column at that time.
There was just so much stuff then.
It was just awful.
Yeah, right.
In fact, if you want a good picture of that incorrect view of planetary astronomy, a good picture of the way it was, look at Blanco and McCaskey's book, The Basic Physics of the Solar System.
Yeah, you'll also find that in Russell Dugan's story.
That's right, yeah.
But these two books together...
really embody that view of the solar system before the old spacecraft, before modern technology was brought to bear on planetary problems, and shows you what a primitive state it was in.
And I guess in a way, even though the stellar guys sneered at planetary stuff largely because of the sensationalism
It was really the lack of applications of things like spectroscopy and large telescopes and even the existing technologies today.
the planetary problems that made planetary astronomy so exceedingly permanent at that time?
That was something I'm certainly going to stress, which is that some of these things could have been uncovered long before they were.
Long before they were.
Long before they were.
Let's get personal for a minute.
All right.
What's the best piece of work you think you've ever done?
You always have the feeling that the paper you're working on now is the finest thing in the world.
I guess, in a way, the best piece of work I've done, apart from what I'm working on now, is a series of review articles I wrote for Nat Carlton's book on pathometry.
I've got three chapters in Volume 12A of Methods of Experimental Physics.
that was published in 1975.
And that's been a very influential and I would say successful review of the subject.
A less successful but I think equally good piece of work is the body of work I did on simulations back in the late 60s and early 70s.
Unfortunately, that has not been influential.

Well, most astronomers are unaware of propagation through turbulence, modern simulation theory, ceiling, and all that stuff that's well understood by optical physicists, communication engineers, oceanographers, and many other people in fields dealing with propagation through turbulence.
Astronomers, unfortunately, were the first people into this field of turbulent propagation, and they fossilized a lot of wrong notions very early.
In particular, the notion that there are independent bright and dark factors argument can be used to estimate the amplitude of simulation.
That argument was recently published last year, most recently published last year in solar physics, at least 30 years after it was known to be wrong.
And I am continually discouraged at how to solve this problem of getting astronomers educated.
The theory is not all that difficult, but it seems to be one we refuse to learn.
because the textbooks are in other fields.
It's the not-invented-here business.
And they simply won't read books written by people who are not a scholar.
Do you have any misfires?
Misfires?
You mean real boo-boos?
Yes.
Sentin bands.
Sentin bands.
I guess the biggest sentin band thing I came up with was when I suggested there might be carbon disulfide on Venus.
And a close companion to that was my suggestion that the lower atmosphere of Venus might contain a large amount of sulfur.
Those are probably my worst two pieces of work.
Any gripes or compliments about the way the USA's handled science and, of course, scientific research grants in particular in the past?
Yeah, let me think about this for a second.
Turn off the tape.
OK.
I think NASA got off on the wrong foot by being created overnight in a rush.
The result was it was staffed with people who were available.
I know there were people who were borrowed from other agencies in the Washington area.
There were a lot of non-astronomers put in.
There were too few people at the start that had the scientific expertise to guide the agency wisely.
That was the error in the beginning.
After a few years, they began getting some scientists involved.

Unfortunately, as the thing grew, it became more and more bureaucratic, and that repelled more and more scientists, so that now it's exceedingly difficult to get anybody with good scientific credentials to help NASA headquarters, or for that matter, any other of these Washington bureaucracies.
And again, the result is that there's not enough scientific input to the policy making.
There's entirely too much bureaucracy that has been shoveled onto the individual scientists, the grant receivers, who have worked through the development of these large
research contract-handling organizations that are connected with universities.
The result is that far too much money is going in the overhead and not enough in the science.
That's another problem.
There's yet another problem in NASA, which I have seen close up, and that is that although they have continually patted themselves on the back for their amount of general expertise
I've actually heard NASA people say that NASA's greatest contribution was learning how to manage these enormously complicated technical projects.
In fact, they have not learned how to manage these enormously complicated technical projects.
Every one of them that I've seen has been done differently.
They always discover that there were serious flaws in the previous project, so they vow to do the next one differently, and they make a whole new set of mistakes the second time around.
My favorite example of horror story is the thing that got me out of the Viking lander camera team.
I was going to these meetings every two weeks in various parts of the country to discuss progress on the cameras.
And at one of these meetings, a guy came up to me and said, hey, we got a problem.
We've just realized that the radio transmitter that sits on the back of the lander is gold coated for thermal control.
And we're worried that the sun will reflect off of this shiny gold coating into the camera, and the camera will be blinded.
And I said, come on.
That's a ridiculous worry.
The sun would have to be just in the right orientation, just the right height above the horizon.
Even if the sun did reflect off of the thing into the camera, it's a scanning system.
The image of the sun is only going to be on the detector for a tenth of a millisecond.
You can forget about it.
You know, it's a solid state detector.
You can't hurt it.
He said, you mean we don't have to paint it brown?
And I said, that's right.
And he said, you've just saved us $30,000.
And it turned out that the $30,000 was not $30,000 worth of brown paint.
And it was not $30,000 worth of testing in thermal vacuum chamber.
It was $30,000 that it cost to print and mail out that boiler plate thing two inches thick every time they made a change in the specification.
So if they changed the line from shall be gold-coated to shall be painted brown, that was $30,000 down the drain.
That kind of was the last straw for me.
All right.
We've done a lot of work from the ground and from spacecraft, and no trace of life or anything approaching it anywhere else in the solar system except Earth.
Yep.
How much do you think this has hurt funding?
A lot?
None at all?
Gee, I don't know if it's made any difference or not.
Unless walking, talking life were discovered somewhere.
You know, if, for example, the lichens that had been expected on Mars by some people had actually been discovered on Mars.
I don't think that would have done much.
You've got to realize that there's something like 10% of the population that thinks the moon landings were fake.
They don't believe any of this stuff anyway.
People in general are pretty ignorant of science, apparently increasingly more so as time goes on.
And I think that unless obviously intelligent life that could compete with us on our own level had been discovered,
I don't think it would have made any ripple in the public.
It would have made a ripple in the academic community, to be sure.
But I'm not sure that it would have had a big impact on funding of NASA.
You have to realize there might also have been a backlash from the fundamentalists against this and demanding that this kind of stuff be shut off.
So I think, on average, it probably made no difference whatsoever.
What's the state of planetary astronomy today?
Oh, shrinking like mad.
Shrinking like mad.
The NASA budget is rapidly being cut.
I read not long ago that 70% of the astronomers in this country, not just planetary, but all astronomers in this country are supported by NASA.
It's creating an employment crisis.
I think what's going to happen is that NASA will shrink back to something closely resembling the old NACA that preceded it, the National Advisory Committee on Aeronautics.

I think it will become an aeronautical engineering research organization, as it was originally, and that the space business will eventually peter out and come to an end, either for lack of funding or because the accumulation of debris in orbit makes it impractical to launch things into space.
into lower Earth orbit anymore.
The Air Force seems ready, willing, and able to do space exploration.
Do you think they'll make the change that they can stand on?
They already are, of course.
Well, I don't know.
I think I'm not plugged into that community, so I can't say how eager they are to get into that kind of stuff.
They may pick up a little of it.
I can't... You see, the Air Force, probably even more than NASA, is interested in flying people around.
I think even more than NASA, they regard that as their primary mission.
And so I think it's unlikely that the Air Force will make it go in place of NASA.
If the Air Force should take on the scientific one, as they did before there was NASA, would that be good or bad or a different performance?
Well, it would be kind of like it was before there was a NASA.
It would be things more oriented toward the Air Force's end than toward astronomers' end.
It would be better than nothing from a scientific point of view.
But again, it would be regarded as kind of marginal funding that a lot of people wouldn't be all that interested in because the airport has its own access to guns.
There was this interesting business recently a few years ago when the airport declassified their active optics research.
And it appears to me that the reason they did that was that...
You can just barely make active optics work on astronomical objects, which are moving across the sky very slowly.
But if you're trying to track incoming missiles or satellites or airplanes and correct their images, they have much higher angular rates of motion across the sky.
The problem is very much more difficult.
And I think the Air Force has probably given up on trying to do it for their purposes.
and turn it over to the astronomers because they realized it would do us some good and it can't do the competition any good because it isn't useful for military use.
And get them some good, favorable publicity.
The problem is that the hardware is still at Air Force prices

if you need a hundred and some actuators per mirror and the actuators cost fifty thousand dollars a piece i think the number of observatories that can afford that is about two one of which is eso and i don't know which is the other but maybe the cat maybe the cat right maybe the cat um
That's a good question.
I guess I would have to say from the current state of funding that they haven't done a good job of selling themselves to the Congress.

From the response I get from people in the street and the interest I see in solar system astronomy in general when I talk to people, I think they've done a fair job of selling themselves to the public.
But the public hasn't
been sufficiently enthusiastic to communicate their interest to their representatives in Congress.
As a result, planetary astronomy has remained near the bottom of Congress's priority list and is rapidly getting cut.
Well, that almost completely answers the next question, which is, do you think that planetary astronomy has changed in any significant way the way the public thinks and views the research?
Oh, yes.
Absolutely.
Absolutely.

I think the thing more than anything else that has changed the public perception of things is the photographs, alas, not by planetary astronomers, but by NASA astronauts on the moon, photographs of the Earth as taken from the moon.
That picture of Earthrise on the moon, I think, has really sunk in on the public consciousness.
And in general, photographs of the Earth from space have, I think, heavily leaned under
the environmental movement and the awareness that the Earth's resources are finite.
Yeah, I think that's been a very beneficial effect.
Not entirely on the part of planetary astronomers, but we've helped a little.
There's a few technical questions.
All right.
Whatever happened to the blue haze and the blue blurry?
That's a very interesting question.
DeVolkalor and I wrote a paper that was never published on that very subject while I was still at Harvard.
IAU symposium that was held in Marfa, Texas.
We again presented this paper.
The glitch in this was originally that one of the snipers was still alive at Lowell, and the book lure had used the sliper plates in gathering his raw material.
The original idea behind the Blue Haze, that there was a large amount of opacity on Mars, was certainly disproved by the Mariner probes.
In fact, that was one of the things that got me in trouble with JPL administration, was that Brad Smith and I sent a letter to science.
Actually, I signed the letter with Brad, and Brad was the guy who mailed it in, unbeknownst to me.

uh sonnet to science showing stating that the third observations of craters and shadows on mars by mariner six and seven showed that there was no large opacity at short wavelengths in these blue photo pictures i then got chewed out by my boss at jpl for not having this letter approved for publication by jpl security who was the owner must have been jerry smith i think at that time
Well, he's immortal in the Keck Telescope because he's the chief engineer on the Keck Telescope.
I think it's the same Jerry Smith.
Anyway, I got chewed out for not having it cleared, and they insisted that I sign, after the fact, a clearance application form to have that letter approved for publication.

Well, anyhow, so we know there's no blue haze, but the odd thing is, and this is what the local study of those old plates showed, there is an enhancement of contrastive features that appears to be statistically significant at small phase angles.
In the sense that in blue photographs, things that seem to be well-known surface features appear more often at small phase angles than at large phase angles.
And this is an effect which is only weakly dependent on seeing and image quality.
And so it's not just due to the image being bigger near opposition.
It's a genuine enhancement of contrast.
I suppose it has to do with the difference in phase function between light areas and dark areas.
But it's still an enigma as to why there is this enhancement in contrast at small phase.
We still never published our paper.

Although it's plainly visible in Schleifer's book on Mars, if you remember the big coffee table book that Schleifer produced with, I believe, Air Force funding, he shows essentially the same kind of figure that we came up with.
All DeVos Miller did was reconfirm that same thing with more statistics and more data.
I think the effect is real if there's an enhancement of contrast in blue photographs at small phase angles.
So that's the blue clearing?
That's the so-called blue clearing, but it's not a blue clearing.
It's a blue contrast change at small phase angles.
Whatever happened to the wave of darkening?
Well, there have been various studies of the wave of darkening.
I think Chick Capon published a number of papers on it.
Who was that guy at Lowell?
Len...
I just didn't keep track of that stuff, Ron.
I can't tell you whatever became of that.
Here's something that you kept up with.
What is the color of Mars?
There's a book called The Red and Green Planet.
I'll tell you, there's another book, which if you want to see the color of Mars, shows you pretty damn accurately the color of Mars.
And that's a nice coffee table book that was put out as a NASA SP by Tim Mutch and the Viking Lander imaging team.
And there are some well-reproduced color pictures in there showing the best reconstructions I know of of the color of Mars.
They...
It was the only spacecraft experiment on which genuine colorimetry was done.
They determined the Munsell specifications for various features in the landscape, rocks, soil, sky, and whatnot.
And that stuff was published in detail in JGR and then was published in a more informal fashion without the Munsell specifications.
in this caucus table book called The Martian Landscape.
And if you want to see what color Mars is, it's well shown in The Martian Landscape.
If you look up the MUNCEL specifications and find out the names that the National Bureau of Standards attached to those colors, they are yellowish brown, various kinds of yellowish brown.
It's about the color of an old rusty nail.
So the brighter is on Mars, the darker is on Mars.
Brighter, darker.
Yellowish brown.
Exactly.
Whatever happened to the ashen light on Venus?
Are you familiar with that?
Yeah, the ashen light.
Well, there's a curious follow-up to the ashen light, you see, and that's this infrared ashen light that has been discovered by David Allen and investigated further by David Crisp.
The thermal radiation from the lower atmosphere that leaks out through the windows between the water and CO2 bands.
There is genuine radiation.
It probably is not visible.
Probably all the stuff that was reported as ashen light by the visual observer is purely optical illusion effect.
But there is this funny successor to the ashen light in the near infrared that's genuine and has been studied.
